Award.AwardTitle: EFRI BSBA: Complex microsystem networks inspired by internal insect physiology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

The objective of this research is to understand how insects produce and control internal flows and to use this knowledge to create novel, highly efficient, bio-inspired fluid-transport systems. Current approaches to flow delivery and regulation in complex microsystems rely on targeted actuation and active control. In contrast, insects have evolved over millions of years to efficiently manage flows using flexible tissues, simple actuation, and passive, distributed control built into the network itself. The approach combines synchrotron x-ray imaging of internal insect dynamics, material characterization of insect vessels, fluid mechanics modeling and experiments, and advanced micromechanical fabrication technology.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research effort includes transformation of the accepted approach to fluid-based transport in small-scale systems, further development of advanced experimental and fabrication techniques, and fundamental advances in the understanding of insect physiology. The proposed research has the potential to change the paradigm for flow delivery and regulation in small-scale systems, leading to new bioengineered tissues and energy-efficient, biomedically-implantable microdevices.

The broader impacts will include integrating the findings from this project into educational programs at the K-12 and university levels. New lessons that integrate biology and engineering will be developed with under-represented students in urban and rural classrooms. The broader public will also be educated through direct involvement with new television and film productions of National Geographic. Additionally, a deeper understanding of how insect respiration and circulation work will lead to novel mechanisms for targeted biocontrol, enabling economically significant advances in agricultural, residential, and commercial pest management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insects are perhaps the world’s most effective microfluidic devices, able to pump blood, air, and food all within a tiny body. No engineered system can match their combination of small size and sophisticated control of flows. However, we only have a rudimentary understanding of how such flows are produced. In this project, we aimed to understand the fundamental principles that insects use to produce respiratory airflows and circulatory blood flows within their bodies, and to apply this knowledge to the design of new microfluidic devices. Previous efforts to use insects as a source of bio-inspired design have focused on external features such as cuticle properties or aerodynamics of flight; here, we turned to the inside of the insect as a source of inspiration.

 

Our studies have revealed new insight into the biomechanical mechanisms that underlie how insects produce airflows using rhythmic tracheal compression, and how respiration interacts with the circulatory system. Using a combination of synchrotron X-ray imaging at Argonne National Laboratory and other physiological techniques, we have identified the relationship between body movement, blood pressure, and compression of the tracheal system in insects such as beetles, roaches, and grasshoppers. Mathematical modeling has shown how two compression locations on a tracheal tube can produce unidirectional airflow, and material testing and finite elemental modeling has helped to understand how such compressions form. Our studies have revealed that tracheal compression even occurs in beetle pupae, a development stage that can be less metabolically active. In pupae, the abdominal pump produces a spike in pressure in the blood, which compresses parts of the tracheal system and forces air out of the body. However, not all abdominal pumps result in tracheal compression—when the tracheal system is sealed, no compression occurs, and no air escapes. This suggests that the abdominal pump may also be functioning to drive blood flow within the body. Our new understanding of respiration and circulation is now being used to develop new microfluidic systems that harness the agility and self-contained nature of flow production by insects.

 

This project has helped to train over thirty graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research that spans fluid mechanics, soft tissue mechanics, insect physiology, and biomechanics. It has also trained multiple high school students and high school STEM teachers from the local area of Appalachia. These teachers have developed new educational material based on the work in our labs, which they have brought back to their classrooms. Due to its interdisciplinary nature, this project was also integrated with an NSF IGERT program at Virginia Tech that trained students at the interface of engineering and biological sciences. Lastly, the findings from this research have been disseminated to the public through scientific papers, websites, television shows, and print media.
